titleStmt.title: A soft robotic gripper with gecko-inspired adhesive

analytic.title: A soft robotic gripper with gecko-inspired adhesive

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Previous work has demonstrated the versatility of soft robotic grippers using simple control inputs. However, these grippers still face challenges in grasping large objects and in achieving high strength grasps. This work investigates the combination of fluidic elastomer actuators and gecko-inspired adhesives to both enhance existing soft gripper properties and generate new capabilities. On rocky or dirty surfaces where adhesion is limited, the gripper retains the functionality of a pneumatically actuated elastomer gripper with no measured loss in performance. Design strategies for using the unique properties of the gecko-inspired adhesives are presented. By modeling fluidic elastomer actuators as a series of joints with associated joint torques, we designed an actuator that takes advantage of the unique properties of the gecko-inspired adhesive. Experiments showed higher strength grasps at lower pressures compared to non-gecko actuators, in many cases enabling the gripper to actuate more quickly and use less energy. The gripper weighs 48.7 g, uses $7.25 of raw materials and can support loads of over 50 N. A second gripper, using three fingers for a larger adhesive surface, demonstrated a grasping force of 111 N (25 lbf) when actuated at an internal pressure of 40 kPa.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE fluidic elastomer actuator has been a promising technology in the fast growing field of soft robotics [1], [2]. Consisting of a hollow elastomer membrane and driven through fluid pressure, these actuators have been used in both mobility systems [3], [4], [5] and in grippers [6], [7], [8]. Fluidic elastomer actuators have become more capable as researchers embed pressure, resistive [9], capacitive [10], magnetic [11], and optoelectronic [12] sensors, and apply them Fig. 1. Gecko elastomer actuator grippers can achieve versatile grasps on complex shapes. The gripper passively deformed and reached this stable grasp to react a 20 degree twist applied to the base of the mug. (Mass of mug 400 g) to medical rehabilitation [13], industrial sorting [14], and oceanographic exploration [6], [15] applications.

Elastomer actuators have proven particularly useful as grippers [14]. Due to their compliance, soft grippers can passively deform to match the shape of various target objects [2]. Both the hollow pressurized structure and soft materials associated with elastomer actuators create a tendency for the actuator to deform and evenly distribute loads, which typically limits the maximum applied force of an actuator to a safe range. This property makes many elastomer actuators suitable for interaction with humans [13] and fragile objects [6]. These actuators are appropriate for use in harsh environments due to their use of resilient elastomeric materials [3], [6]. Advances in efficient geometries [16], self-healing materials [17], and multi-material composite structures [1], [15] have enhanced the capabilities of these grippers.

Despite the promise of elastomer actuators and recent advances, challenges persist. The regulation of pressure through motion of fluid can introduce delays from 50 ms up to a few seconds [3], [16]. Soft materials complicate state estimation as material deformations are challenging to model [18]. Additionally, elastomer actuators cannot transmit as much force and torque as grippers with rigid links. Current actuators increase fluid pressure to increase stiffness and support larger loads, an energy intensive approach that has led to modest performance improvements [6], [19]. These challenges contribute to a lack of control authority.

The inherent compliance of an elastomer actuator is, of course, largely responsible for many of their desirable properties. However, the grip strength of an elastomer actuator relying upon a frictional contact is bounded by the stiffness of the actuator, friction coefficient, and the ability of the actuator to generate a normal force. Low grasp forces reduce the ability of elastomer actuator grippers to support high accelerations, jerks, or vibrations [18]. Furthermore, grasps of large objects are challenging, restricting elastomer actuator grippers primarily to objects smaller than themselves [20].

To address many of these challenges, we introduce an elastomer actuator with a surface layer of gecko-inspired adhesives: the Gecko Elastomer Actuator. Gecko-inspired adhesives are a class of materials with micro-structured surfaces that generate adhesion using van der Waals forces [21]. Geckoinspired adhesives can be used not only for adhesion, but also to dramatically enhance friction properties [22]. The adhesives are controllable and can engage or disengage at low forces [23], [24]. Because the adhesives are sensitive to the direction of applied load and to the real area of contact, the gripper must account for several new design principles, discussed below. The resulting gecko elastomer actuator grippers enable: 1) high strength grasps at low actuator pressures, 2) grasps of objects too large to enclose, 3) increased control authority, 4) faster actuation (through lower operating pressures), and 5) additional grasp options.

In the following sections, we discuss previous work in soft grippers and gecko-inspired adhesive grippers (Section II), design principles for proper use of the adhesives, a model to aid the design of elastomer actuators for gecko adhesives, and the fabrication process (Section III). In Section IV, we present experimental results evaluating the model, compare the gecko elastomer actuator to non-adhesive grippers, and demonstrate a high-strength grip. We end with conclusions and a discussion of future work in Section V II. BACKGROUND There are two primary topologies of fluid driven elastomer grippers: digitated grippers and pouch grippers. Soft digitated grippers primarily use bending fluidic elastomer actuators, but can also employ cable drives, dielectric actuators, liquid crystal elastomer, or shape memory alloys [1], [2]. Variable stiffness grippers utilize particle jamming or magnetorheological fluid to rigidize, or simply grip by creating a suction contact [1], [25]. Variable stiffness grippers show high versatility and strength, but only on objects from specific classes of shapes. They typically require a large compressive preload and do not allow in-hand manipulation or dexterity. Soft digitated grippers utilize low stiffness to conform to objects and grasp with load-controlled friction [26]. These grippers are limited by their applied normal force or bending stiffness; these properties are typically coupled and depend on the internal fluid pressure. Recent works [19], [6] use pressures in excess of 300 kPa, enabling grasp of heavier loads. However, use of higher pressures comes with increased energy loss in fluid transmission, risk of rupture, and reduced surface conformation. The introduction of gecko-inspired adhesives eliminates Fig. 2. In many cases, the gecko elastomer actuator gripper does not depend on adhesion, but is enhanced by it. On dusty, irregular, or porous objects where adhesive performance is low, gecko elastomer actuator grippers still utilize force closure. (Mass of rock 150 g) the need for large normal forces or increased bending stiffness and thus decouples the grip strength from internal pressure for fluid elastomer actuators. This innovation allows a gecko elastomer actuator (Fig. 11) to lift 11.3 kg at only 40 kPa of pressure.

Gecko-inspired adhesives are inspired by micro-and nanostructures found on the animals' toes [21]. These engineered structures are directional-when loaded in a preferred shear direction, they exhibit strong adhesion, but allow low-force release when loaded in other directions or when no shear load is applied [23]. Gecko-inspired adhesives can have long life, maintaining adhesion in the lab up to at least 30 000 cycles [27]. Performance is temporarily reduced in dusty conditions, but the adhesives are easily cleaned by contact with a tacky surface.

Synthetic materials that mimic some gecko adhesive properties fall into three classes: nanostructures, isotropic stalks, and directional stalks, with no material yet matching all of the amazing properties of the animal's toe pad. Both nanostructures, typically made of dense carbon nanotube bundles [28], [29], and vertical stalks of soft polymer with mushroom shaped tips [30], [31] provide strong adhesion, but require high forces to engage and release. Directional micro-scale stalks with mushroom shaped tips [32], [33] are controllable, but require the proper application of loads to realize adhesion. Directional wedge-shaped gecko adhesives [34] were chosen for this work due to their strong friction and adhesion properties, reusability, material compatibility with the elastomer actuators, and the ability to easily release an object as well as provide a strong grip.

Several soft grippers have utilized adhesives. Flexible electrostatic adhesive fingers have been used to manipulate soft goods [35]. Song et al. demonstrated an elastomer membrane coated in gecko-like hairs that showed normal load distribution across three-dimensional surfaces using a vacuum behind the membrane [36]. Due to the stretchable membrane and required preload, the gripper is best suited for loads of only a few newtons. Rigid-tile gecko-adhesive grippers are capable of supporting high forces on flat surfaces, with applications in industrial automation and in-space operations including capture of orbital debris [34], micro-gravity mobility [37], and temporary anchoring [38]. However, these grippers lose adhesion on curvatures with a diameter less than a few meters. Dedicated curved surface grippers exploit adhesion-controlled friction to enable grasping at very low surface pressures [20], [34]. These curved surface grippers engage the entire adhesive area creating very strong grasps but are only suitable for smooth objects within a range of curvatures that depend on the size of the gripper. The gripper also relies on outriggers to engage the adhesive, which precludes wrapped grasps, limits the ability to grasp irregular objects, and increases the chance of damage in unstructured environments.

div.head: A. Design principles
div.p: Three design principles enable effective utilization of geckoinspired adhesives on a fluidic elastomer actuator:
1) The area of contact between the actuator and target surface should be maximized to engage as many adhesive features as possible [21].

2) The distribution of stress across the adhesives should be as uniform as possible to enable load sharing [27]. 3) A shear load at the contact area must be generated to engage the gecko-inspired adhesive [38].

In cases where these principles are not met, the benefits of the adhesive are sacrificed, but the gripper recovers the properties of a typical elastomer actuator gripper (Fig. 2). Each microscopic wedge on the adhesive film produces a relatively small amount of adhesion and friction on its own; it is through load sharing that large forces are supported. This property drives the first and second principles enumerated above. To engage many of the wedges, a large area of the actuator must be in contact, and furthermore, if wedges are not loaded evenly, some will become overloaded and detach while others are not contributing.

To fulfill the second principle, a flexible but inextensible strain-limiting layer is used. In previous work, these layers were used as a structural asymmetry to convert expansion of the chambers of elastomer actuators into bending [1], [7], [15]. In the gecko elastomer actuator, the strain-limiting layer also ensures that all adhesive wedges in contact are loaded evenly in shear and that the actuator cannot stretch. Rigidly securing the strain-limiting layer at the base of the gripper creates an inextensible load path for the high force loads enabled by the adhesives.

The third principle can be satisfied either actively, by applying a shear load to symmetrically opposed pads of adhesive [34], [37], [38], or passively, by using the geometry inherent to the object being grasped [20], [34]. This latter approach only applies to objects with curvature; to grasp flat surfaces, an active shear preload must be applied. Effective adhesion to a flat surface requires the use of materials with high bending stiffness to distribute the adhesive loads. Since elastomer actuators typically have low bending stiffness, their performance on flat surfaces will be low. To grasp these surfaces effectively, gecko elastomer actuators require an actuation-independent stiffening mechanism, such as a jamming component or phase transition element [25].

div.head: B. Modeling the torque of an elastomer joint
div.p: A computationally tractable modeling approach, approximating fluidic elastomer actuators as a series of joints, enables the design of elastomer actuators to address the first and second design principles. With narrowly spaced and thin walled elastomer pressure chambers, we can design to a specific torque profile. With more joints, each experiences a smaller bend angle. Thinner membranes are more difficult to manufacture but take less pressure to deflect and are less dependent on boundary conditions, allowing fast actuation with minimal energy input [16]. Our actuator required 15.7 mJ of energy to deform 270 • .

Elastomer actuators provide an active mechanism for controlling the surface area in contact. Positive pressure bends the actuators towards an object. Applying a vacuum bends the actuator away and disengages the gripper. Increasing actuator pressure also stiffens the actuator, useful for applying torques. However, the profile of torque τ at point s along an actuator of length L must not exceed the Hirose distribution [39].

Any monotonically decreasing torque profile that is upper bounded by Eq. 1 and lower bounded by τ(L) = 0, will maintain surface contact, but with a non-uniform normal pressure. A torque profile greater than Eq. 1 will have outer joints that overpower inner joints and concentrate contact area into small regions. We present a model of elastomer joint torque that enables design of a specific torque profile.

We assume that strain only occurs at the thin-membrane face, that the entire membrane face is in contact, and that the effect of the joint angle on the moment arm is negligible. With these assumptions, the internal pressure and chamber geometry directly relate to joint torque. A f is the area of the face in contact, P is the internal chamber pressure, d is the distance from the neutral axis to the centroid of A f (Fig. 3):
div.formula: τ joint = P • A f • d(2)
div.p: This torque model allows the design of an elastomer actuator to meet a specific torque profile. Given the profile in Eq. 1, if the hollow chamber geometry is comprised of semicircular faces with radius r resting at the neutral axis, we can calculate the required the radius as a function of position along the finger s. For ease of manufacture, we do not change the outer dimensions of the actuator.
div.formula: A f (s) = π 2 • r(s) 2 and d(s) = 4 3π • r(s)

div.head: and torques
div.formula: τ joint (s) = 2P 3 • r(s) 3 and τ 0 = πP 2 • r 0 (s) 3
div.p: Setting the distribution τ joint (s) equal to Eq. 1, the distribution of r along the actuator length s is

This model can be adapted for different chamber geometries and torque profiles. Given the inherent inaccuracies in the assumptions, this model serves primarily as a tool for designing a torque profile rather than for estimation and control. Section IV contains model validation data, and demonstrates successful pressurization of an elastomer actuator without loss of contact area.

div.head: C. Materials & manufacturing
div.p: This manufacturing process ensures that the adhesives form a smooth flat face, the bending stiffness of the actuator is low, and the stresses are transfered to the rigid base. The manufacturing process begins with casting a set of hollow elastomer chambers (Fig. 4, ) following a technique modified from [7], [15], [16]. To improve the fidelity of the designed torque profile, we use a high number of internal chambers to minimize the joint angles along the actuator. Each internal chamber is only 2 mm wide, with 0.56 mm thick strips of polycarbonate used during casting to create thin gaps between chambers. The thin membranes have wall thickness 0.9 mm while all other elastomer walls are at least 2.5 mm thick. These design values were near the limits of the manufacturing process and were chosen to best respect the assumptions of the model. This choice ensures most of the deflection while actuating is in the thin membranes, supporting assumptions from the model and allowing for a fast, low energy actuator. The resulting actuator bends 270 at 17 kPa with an input of 15.7 mJ of energy and takes less than 0.4 s.

To provide rigid mounting points for the strain-limiting layer (Fig. 4, {), a 3-D printed anchor (Fig. 4, }) (FormLabs) and silicone pneumatic tubing (Fig. 4,~) are cast directly with the chambers. With unsealed elastomer chambers (DragonSkin 20), we begin with (Fig. 4-A) creating gecko-inspired wedges (Fig. 4, y) by casting MoldStar-30 on a wax daughter mold (Fig. 4,x) and allowing partial cure (20 min at 50 • C). We then build up the structural layers (Fig. 4-B), comprised of three layers of DragonSkin-20 spun at 800 rpm for 1 minute. The layer interfacing the wedge layer (Fig. 4,z) is cast before the wedges have fully cured to increase the bonding strength of dissimilar silicones. The strain-limiting layer contains a polyester mesh and a final interface layer (Fig. 4,|) is cast above to seal any air channels trapped in the strain-limiting layer and to ensure a flat surface. To conclude the process (Fig. 4-C), the elastomer chambers are bonded to the interface layer by pressing the chambers onto a thicker layer of uncured DragonSkin (400 rpm for 2 minutes). Fig. 4. Multi-step manufacturing process. A thin film of gecko adhesive is cast from a mold (A). Structural layers are built up on the adhesives, incorporating a strain-limiting layer to support loads (B). The resulting membrane is bonded to the chamber geometry and plumbing (C). The process can be generalized to suit a broad range of adhesive daughter molds & the variety of approaches used to cast elastomer actuator chambers. Numbered labels match text.

The gecko elastomer actuator has only a few components and the total cost of raw materials is only $7.25 at quantity 1 ($1.50 silicones, $1.50 pneumatic tubing and fittings, $2.75 3-D printed components, $1 strain-limiting layer, $0.50 wax for adhesive mold). The complexity of adding gecko-inspired adhesives to elastomer actuators varies depending on the adhesive mold. Not all molds are reusable, and design or fabrication of a mold from scratch can be an intensive process. Since we employ reusable molds and cast from a master developed in prior work [21], [33], adding the adhesive layer does not add significant cost or complexity to the manufacturing process (<$2, <1 h).

div.head: A. Model evaluation
div.p: Tests performed at various chamber pressures and joint angles validate model predictions of the joint torque generated by elastomer actuators. Rigid brackets on each end of the joint provided an inextensible fixture and fixed moment arm for force measurement. The bottom bracket enforced the angle of the joint. Torque was calculated from force measurements recorded using a force gauge (Mark-10 M5-10). Fig. 5 shows the experimental setup.

When the joint angle is at zero degrees, the model accurately predicted the output torque with two notable exceptions; nonlinearity not captured by the model and the measured torque eventually exceeded the predicted torque (see in Fig. 6). This nonlinearity can be explained by the thin-membrane not translating evenly but instead stretching from a bounding edge. Consider the real area in contact between two adjacent faces, denoted by A c . At P = 0, A c = 0 but with increased pressure and strain, A c approaches A f . At a large enough pressure, the membrane bulges outwards and will begin to yield A c > A f . A higher joint angle then serves to exacerbate the nonlinearity. With a larger joint angle, the initial gap between faces is larger, requring additional pressure and strain to reach A c = 0. This explains the larger overprediction of the model at lower pressures at higher joint angles in Fig. 6. Furthermore, given the semi-circle geometry of the faces, d varies not only with r but also with P, resulting in reduced model accuracy at low pressures. While the accuracy of this modeling approach depends on actuator design, position, and pressure, several factors mitigate modeling error when used for design of a torque profile: 1) the chamber pressure is uniform within an actuator, 2) the discrepancy between modeled and measured torque is minimized as P increases, and 3) the use of many joints reduces the angle in each joint for a given actuator posture. For these reasons, we believe that this model allows for sufficiently accurate design of a specific torque profile. We evaluate the behavior of complete actuators to support this claim.

We used Frustrated Total Internal Reflection (FTIR) to validate actuator behavior with a torque profile described by Eq. 1. FTIR measures the real area of contact between two surfaces [20]. We built a cylindrical FTIR sensor with white LEDs illuminating the edge a polycarbonate surface. We compared an actuator with torque profile according to Eq. 1 with an actuator described by a uniform profile τ(s) = C. Varying the pressure in an actuator while in contact with the FTIR surface highlights the effect of the torque profile of an actuator. As seen in Fig. 8, the addition of pressure to the uniform torque profile actuator had the effect of decreasing contact area. Distal joints overpowered more proximal joints, lifting large portions of the finger off of the surface. The actuator with the torque profile defined in Eq. 1 maintained high contact area across a wide range of pressures. This actuator experienced a small area loss due to internal pneumatic chambers bulging against the surface, but this loss is small.

div.head: B. Large object grasp
div.p: Gecko-inspired adhesives enable the gripper to grasp objects too wide to be enclosed. Fig. 9 compares the grasp capability offered by otherwise identical elastomer actuators with and without gecko adhesive when grasping large objects. The actuators have a width of 2 cm and length of 6 cm. Using 27 kPa of pressure, we measured grasp force on a set of polycarbonate cylinders (diameters 57 mm to 203 mm) using a force gauge (Mark-10). The two smallest targets allowed the grippers to wrap beyond the widest point of the cylinder. Data for the non-adhesive gripper shows a significant difference in pullout force for this case, when a wrap grasp is possible. The This improved performance aligns with prior models of gecko-inspired adhesive grippers [20]. The adhesive grippers exploit adhesion-controlled friction rather than load-controlled friction [26]. Both grippers apply force to the object through frictional forces. In the case of the non-gecko gripper, this friction depends on the normal load applied by the actuators. For the gecko adhesive gripper, the friction is adhesioncontrolled, meaning the friction force is dependent on the total contact area, not normal force. This allows the gecko elastomer gripper to support large grasp forces-with low fluid pressures-by regulating contact area.

A benefit of the gecko elastomer actuator is stronger grasp at lower actuation pressures. Fig. 10 compares the grip strength of the grippers using gecko elastomer actuators and non-gecko actuators on both large and small cylinders across a range of fluid pressures. On the 203 mm cylinder, the effect of pressure is small for both actuators, but the gecko elastomer actuator gripper supported an additional 6.5 N at all pressures. On the small radius cylinders using force-closure grasps, the gecko actuators significantly outperformed the non-gecko actuator. At low pressures the gecko elastomer actuator gripper yielded a rapid increase in grip strength as the additional pressure created more real area of contact and adhesive engagement. This reaches a maximum when all of the adhesive area is engaged. Once this maximum is reached, additional pressure will still stiffen the actuator but does not force the actuator off the surface.

div.head: C. High strength grip
div.p: To show the performance improvement of using gecko elastomer actuators in wrapped grasps, we designed a highload gripper. This gripper (Fig. 11) uses three actuators for increased contact area and stability, wider elastomer actuators for increased surface area (3.6 cm by 8 cm), and high stiffness nylon/carbon-fiber composite brackets. The gripper can operate at higher pressure to maximize the contribution of both adhesion-controlled friction and bending stiffness from the elastomer actuators. The elastomer actuators create force closure and the gecko-inspired adhesives prevent shear sliding, significantly enhancing pull out strength. The high-strength gripper supports over 111 N (25 lbf) at a chamber pressure of 40 kPa (Fig. 11).

This demonstration was conducted on a KUKA LBR iiwa robotic arm. The gripper can lift over 111 N, measured by the mass of the payload. This grip was secure, repeatable, and robust to the dynamic effects associated with accelerations in the payload. The teleoperated robotic arm picked the payload up from rest, lifted and translated the payload, released the payload in a controlled manner, and did not need a planned trajectory or precise payload position. This procedure was repeated several times, with variations in the payload position and gripper orientation to demonstrate robustness to misalignment. The gripper does not exhibit any visible plastic deformation or loss of performance after testing (over 25 trials). Additional media and information can be found in the supplementary video.

div.head: D. Control authority
div.p: Gecko elastomer actuators provide improved control authority for manipulation tasks. The ability to achieve higher ultimate grip strengths on many objects allows manipulation of heavier objects as well as more rapid accelerations of objects during tasks. This is especially useful for pick and place operations, where speed is critical. Additionally, because lower pressures can be used for gecko elastomer actuators, Fig. 12. Elastomer actuator grippers are capable of a wide range of stable grasps. Gecko-inspired adhesives enhance grasp choice by reducing the minimum chamber pressure for a stable grasp and by increasing grip strength at a given chamber pressure. Gecko-inspired adhesives also enable grasps that are not possible through load-controlled friction.

div.head: TABLE I COMPARISON OF RECENT HIGH-LOAD FLUIDIC ELASTOMER ACTUATORS
Gripper
div.p: Pressure (kPa) Lift force (N) Yap, 2016 [19] 300 25 Galloway 2016, [6] 310 52.9 Gecko-Fig. 1 28 50 Gecko-Fig. 11 40 111

actuation is faster and more efficient. The gecko elastomer actuator maintains the low energy input and fast actuation seen in actuators optimized for these properties while using adhesion-enhanced friction for higher strength grips. Most soft grippers must undergo significant pressurization to become stiff enough to lift large loads. The gecko-adhesives remove requirement and allow for the actuator to remain much softer, while supporting similarly large loads (Table 1). For reference, Mosadegh et al. presented a gripper that actuated 270 • in 200 ms at 117 kPa with 115.9 mJ of energy input [16]. The pair of gecko elastomer actuator fingers require 31.4 mJ of energy input to actuate the same distance, taking 400 ms at 50 kPa.

Gecko elastomer actuators also provide fundamentally new capabilities where adhesion makes previously unstable grasps possible (Fig. 9). This increase makes a much wider variety of configurations for grasping a given object and is more robust to positioning errors in the grasp location. These factors are particularly important given the imprecise state estimation and actuation time delays [14] typical of soft robots. Fig. 12 illustrates the variety of grasp options available for handling a coffee mug, many of which would not be possible with a non-gecko elastomer actuator gripper. IEEE ROBOTICS AND AUTOMATION LETTERS. PREPRINT VERSION. ACCEPTED DECEMBER, 2017

div.head: V. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: This work shows how gecko elastomer actuators deliver new capabilities (grasping large curvature and new grasp configurations) and improve performance in other cases (higher strength grasps, lower fluid pressures, faster operation). This work serves as a guide for making gecko elastomer actuators and demonstrates their applicability to high-load applications. When the adhesives do not contribute to grip strength, the performance of non-gecko actuators is recovered. Reducing energy input and increasing grip strength will help extend the use of soft robotics into industrial automation and other applications. New models that promote surface conformation across a range of fluid pressures may also be applied broadly to other fluid elastomer actuators.

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig.3. Model of a fluidic elastomer actuator as a series of discrete joints. Indicated are the joint angle (1); the thin membrane that undergoes the most deformation, side profile (2) and the area of the thin membrane (3) denoted by A f ; and the distance from the neutral axis of the actuator to the centroid of the thin membrane (4) denoted by d.

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. Experimental setup to validate the torque generated by a single elastomer actuator joint. The joint is fixed to the desired angle by the combination of the forge gauge and a 3D printed support; the joint is then pressurized as force readings are taken with the gauge.

figure.head: ig. 6 . 2 Fig. 7 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 7. Cylindrical FTIR sensor used to measure contact area. Rings of LEDs illuminate the ends of the cylinder. A wide angle camera located on the axis of the cylinder captures the results. Images are captured with minimal ambient light, and subtraction of a dark frame in post processing calibrates the sensor.

figure.head: Fig. 8 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 8. Images captured on FTIR sensor. Bright areas indicate contact between the actuator and surface. Actuator A: uniform torque profile τ(s) = C. Actuator B: Torque profile follows Eq. 1. Actuator A lost significant contact area (highlighted in red) due to most of the actuator flexing away from the surface. Actuator B can maintain a high degree of contact area during pressurization.

figure.head: Fig.
figure.figDesc: Fig. Gecko elastomer actuator grippers provide a stronger grasp across a wide range of cylinders.

figure.head: Fig. 10 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 10. Evaluation of chamber pressure for gecko/non-gecko elastomer actuator grip strength.

figure.head: Fig. 11 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 11. Three actuators create a wrapped grasp, engaging the gecko-inspired adhesives and supporting an 11.3 kg (25 lb) mass at 40 kPa.
